To facilitate subsequent discussion, each N. glauca flower produces in Greece an average of 23.5 μL of nectar with sucrose mean concentration of 25.2% [ 17]. Taking into account that the minimum daily need of an adult bee for sucrose is 4000 μg [ 39, 40] it is estimated that each bee will consume approximately 16 μL of nectar (see Eq. 4) if all sucrose daily needs is to be covered from N. glauca nectar. Considering the significant fluctuation of anabasine concentration in N. glauca nectar ranging from 0.39 μg/mL [ 22], to 5 μg/mL [ 16] a single honeybee may be exposed daily from 6 to 80 ng of anabasine (see Eq. 5).
